title: Greece’s ancient sites are fascinating
text:
Greece’s ancient sites are fascinating Michele Gandolf , San Francisco Chronicle By Michele Gandolfo Published 4:36 pm, Thursday, August 6, 2015 Michele, Katie, Gregory and Rick Gandolfo of San Francisco at Lions Gate, ancient Mycenae, Greece. Why I went: We wanted to explore some of the ancient sites of Greece and to visit a Greek island. 
Don’t miss: Visiting the ancient sites with a guide and exploring the alley streets of the Plaka in Athens. The island of Hydra is quaint and doesn’t have any cars; you walk or ride a donkey in Hydra Town and take a water taxi to the beaches. 
Don’t bother: With fancy restaurants. The neighborhood cafes serve delicious Greek dishes, and the wines are inexpensive. We found everyone to be friendly and welcoming. 
Coolest souvenir: A bottle of Mastiha, a spirit unique to Greece and introduced to us at a rooftop bar in Athens with a view of the Acropolis. 
Worth a splurge: Renting a car to explore Delphi and the ancient city sites of Corinth and Mycenae on the Peloponnese. The freedom to map your own itinerary is worth the expense of not purchasing a group bus tour. 
Wish I’d packed: More time; we enjoyed Greece immensely. 
Other comments: Everyone speaks some English, so we didn’t have any difficulties communicating with locals. Be sure to try the wonderful Greek wines.
